nodes.bodyText: Formatting looks non-standard in these file. Also, you're missing the copyright notices.

This example is really an example of API usage, just using the SDK classes. I think these examples should focus on operator/application owner setup/configuration of the SDK, rather than repeating API usage examples.
isn't that covered by ConfigureSpanProcessorExample and ConfigureTraceExample?

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * Java 1.8.231
          
          
            
            * Java 1.8 or higher
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@
+# SDK Usage Examples
+
+This is a simple example that demonstrates how to use and configure the OpenTelemetry SDK. 
+
+## Prerequisites
+* Java 1.8.231

nodes.bodyText: that would fit well into your DemoUtils class
You could add a note on what those attributes would be about.

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    .spanBuilder("#4 - SAMPLED this trace will be showed in the console output")
          
          
            
                    .spanBuilder("#4 - SAMPLED this trace will be shown in the console output")

That's likely to break when the SDK is developed further and wouldn't be discovered easily since the build wouldn't break.
Do you think it would make sense to (cleanly) expose the configured span processors on TracerSdkProvider?
I think this question should be addressed in an issue so everyone can contribute with their opinion.
will the jar end up being runnable with java -jar ... ?

nodes.bodyText: You right, I should add the cmd line to run the examples.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@

+

nodes.bodyText: we should probably include the google java format plugin so we can get the examples to automatically match the rest of the codebase.
we should depend on 0.3.0-SNAPSHOT until we get that published, since these examples look pretty out of date. thoughts?
I'm fine either way but also tend towards using 0.3.0.
for examples, we should use the Logging exporter, since it will actually output visible information
Mention it is printing custom information, for the sake of the example?
Mention this is a rather uncommon case?
I will remove complete this case and move the explanatory comments into the custom SpanProcessor in ConfigureTraceExample.
why not just tracerProvider.shutdown()
TraceConfig config = tracerProvider.getActiveTraceConfig();
TraceConfig newConf = tracerProvider.getActiveTraceConfig().toBuilder().setMaxNumberOfAttributes(1).build();
Same comment, always start from the currentConfig to update one argument :)
Just use the simplespanprocessor + loggingexporter?

I wanted to showcase the possibility to create your own span processor with this class. Furthermore, with this class the attributes are pretty printed while with the loggingexporter they would be embedded with other span information.

Then split it into one example to configure the SDK using TraceConfig + Views for metrics when they will be available. Second example to create your own SpanProcessor. I think most of the people are interested in the first example.

I really like this example.
nit: Should this be public if you have a public main, sorry haven not written too many main functions in my life?
It is not required to execute the main, but the convention says this should be public since its the name of the file!
Can we just remove this for the moment? Is it a big downgrade in experience?

@@ -0,0 +1,61 @@
+/*

+
+package io.opentelemetry.sdk.example.unsafe;
+
+import io.opentelemetry.sdk.trace.MultiSpanProcessor;
+import io.opentelemetry.sdk.trace.SpanProcessor;
+import io.opentelemetry.sdk.trace.TracerSdk;
+import java.lang.reflect.Field;
+import java.lang.reflect.Method;
+import java.util.List;
+
+/**
+ * These methods use reflection to access private fields of the tracer. This is meant as
+ * demonstration only. It is SEVERELY discouraged to access private fields since they are shared
+ * among different threads.
+ */
+@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
+public class DemoUtils {

nodes.bodyText:
I know this is a hacky way of doing things that will hardly scale with further changes. Unfortunately, I don't have another solution for showing to the end user of the ConfigureSpanProcessorExample example which SpanProcessor is initialized.
Would you suggest to remove the console output for that example along with the DemoUtils class?

nodes.bodyText: After a tiny bit of investigation, this requires to add such a method in all SpanProcessor implementation. I will simply add a comment that tells the reader which SpanProcessor is registered.
